job_title: Coordinator III in Saint Paul, MN

job_title: Program Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Strong sense of community. Ideologically diverse. Very well-resourced compared to other universities. Rob Vischer and Eddy Rojas are phenomenal leaders. You can find many smart and talented people doing cool things across campus.
cons: Many things become exhausting after a while: the class divide between faculty and staff, ideological diversity, microaggressions, Minnesota winter. Health insurance was just re-negotiated with United Healthcare, which is a horrible company to work with. If you are a POC or queer, make sure that the coworkers in your department are people with whom you want to work. Even though tuition remission is 100% for most programs, UST tuition is so high that tax payroll deductions can become insane. For example, after taking a J-Term and Spring class, the deduction was $375 per paycheck to cover the taxes on a summer MBA. If you are planning to use the tuition remission benefit for a master's or doctoral degree, read up on IRS requirements for taxable tuition remission and do the math yourself. Payroll will not give you information about what they are deducting until AFTER they do it.

UST has quite the reputation of entitlement among their students, and believe me, if you are an adjunct there, you will be a huge target since they cannot touch the tenured employees. Be ready to fight for your decisions and reasonings behind your gradings if you give grades below an A.

review_title: A really good place to work!
job_title: in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Tuition benefits are good to have access to and the university has several good programs which are competitive with other schools in the area.  It  is also the largest private school in the state and that carries with it certain benefits.  It is fun to work around students and when your customer is very young and has a unique point of view, you're constantly presented with new challenges.  This is especially true of the technology on campus because the "millenials" have different expectations than the older generation that runs the place.  The focus for most departments isn't on making sales goals.
cons: Because most of the departments don't have a goal as far as how much revenue they contribute to generating, it is difficult to find metrics for doing performance evaluations.  Parking is nearly impossible when the students are on campus and permits get pricy.  The location is great, but the neighbors often complain about what the university and the students are doing, sometimes rightly so.  Because the university has a smaller number of administrative positions, job advancement can be a little limited and because it's easy to know and work with a good number of individuals on campus, it can be difficult to move around.

job_title: Graduate Student in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The data science program is very practical and hands-on.
cons: There isn't a strong emphasis on theory.

job_title: Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: It is no exaggeration to say that I have loved nearly everything about working at St Thomas.  Colleagues are talented, dedicated, and down-to-earth. Faculty and staff are committed to forming students not only into excellent lawyers but holistically good human beings. President & Dean regularly grant gift days on top of vacation time and PTO. Retirement benefits cannot be beat. Ongoing access to professional development and tuition remission for various programs. Supervisors are as flexible (within reason) to encourage staff to attend campus-wide events and take classes. Campus facilities are beautiful. Employees are genuinely committed to living out the mission.
cons: The largely homogeneous student body and faculty sometimes make it difficult to live out the welcoming dimension of the mission. Commitment to political diversity and academic freedom also becomes a voice for well-meaning but racist faculty. Leadership have made a public and widespread commitment to combat racism but it remains to be seen how effective this will be long-term.

job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
students are nice and the rates are fair
they provide all kinds of events and services to make students' life more fun and easier, especially for international students
cons: Not think of any... I had really good time here. I learn, make friends while getting pay. What can I complain about? But if you want to earn more, you should really consider jobs or internship off the campus.

job_title: Coordinator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: You will get to work with incredibly smart and passionate people. Everyone throughout the university is committed to the common good. Authentic sense of camaraderie among the staff. Frequent free meals at campus events. Retirement and education benefits are great.
cons: Salaries are not up to market standards. My exact position is posted at other midwestern universities for 4, 6, 8K more per year. Many departments across the university have experienced a significant reduction in faculty/staff but continue to expand programs. In other words, we're doing more with less and not getting paid for it. It makes working/going to school nearly impossible if one aspires to take advantage of the education benefit.

job_title: Security Analyst in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
- Beautiful campus.
- Windows, Office, etc are all current versions.
- Workstations are modern.
- Tuition remission
- There are some nice, motivated people.
cons:
- Egos abound: nobody wants to do what's requested of them without a diatribe about why they don't want to do it.
- Most of their solutions are half-implemented, and nobody seems to be interested in completing them.
- No centralized management means nobody is held to account if they become a road-block.
- Office environment for IT is a dingy basement with no break room; you have to wash your dishes in the bathroom sink. Appetizing.
- Their IT budget seemed minuscule considering their obvious needs.
- You will be walking a quarter a mile to and from your car every day, and you have to pay for a parking permit from their own parking ramp.

review_title: Moderate Salary and Little Room for Advancement- Made up by Excellent Benefits
job_title: in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Saint Thomas has an excellent environment for working in that it is cognizant of life work balance and promotes that among its staff.  The culture is friendly and and fellow employees tend to be supportive of each others work.  

The benefits are quite good at St. Thomas in comparison to other companies and institutions.  Staff and faculty can make use of state of the art athletic facility for a fee that is reimbursed at the end of the term. 

Finally, for the most part there is room for some creativity for some staff members.
cons:
The following seem to be some areas that St. Thomas needs to work on:
1) The administration (President and Vice President) are for the most part alumni of the university and have been in their posts for at least 10+ years, if not 20.  While in some sense this could be good, the administration has seriously missed some wonderful opportunities for university advancement and are often incapable of really seeing beyond a rather limited world view.
2) My experience, and the accounts of colleagues of mine, have shown that middle management (Directors) can either be strong or poor leaders.  My own director was a poor manager as he had little vision or foresight for leading the division.  Moreover, my director was often disconnected from what was actually going on and the team often had to lead him.  I have heard much worse from others about their directors being simply incompetent but upper management is often afraid to remove them as it may cause trouble.
3) While benefits are strong, St. Thomas, like so many other institutions, are slowly decreasing support for those benefits.  The rates are going up, and my sense is that in the long run the university will not be able to sustain its current model.

St. Thomas is at an interesting point in its history.  Student numbers are going down and the university is desperately trying to recruit more students, sometimes at the expense of attracting unqualified students.  In addition, there could potentially be a challenge for the university down the road in that the university has placed a tremendous amount of money in creating state of the art facilities and resources, but is not entirely prepared for the decrease in attendance which will have a tremendous effect on its income.  Finally, its ambitious capitol campaign is struggling to meet its $500m goal and stands currently at just short of $400m.

review_title: Hard working students and even harder working Professors!
job_title: Tour Guide in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The professors in the science department really love what they do and go over and above what is asked of them! It is a challenging subject, but I left St. Thomas feeling like I actually learned the material- not just memorized it for a test.
cons: Not very diverse. Programs are still growing so connections through St. Thomas are looking more and more hopeful every day!

review_title: Outdated teaching and incompetent university leadership
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Saint Paul, MN
pros: There are many students who are dedicated to learning. Beautiful and well maintained urban campus.
cons:
This university caters to middle class white local Catholic students. The talks about diversification of people, culture, and curricula are all just for show, and the leadership makes little effort to diversify. Many of the faculty, again predominantly white, middle class, are superficial, petty, jealous, and unprofessional. There is too much emphasis on getting good evaluation from the students. Instead of teaching what is essential for the course, the instructors are pressured to make the students feel good. Good university education must challenge the students to think critically and transform their ways of seeing the world. Sometimes the students may feel the pain of re-examining what they had previously believed and what they had cherished. If the instructors are pressured to get good reviews from students more than anything, all these "transformative" teachings become too risky.  

The scholarship and teaching of many of the faculty members are outdated.  Check the faculty publications and course pages, most of which are available on the web for anyone to browse. It would not take long for an academic in a similar field to get an idea where the quality of this institution stands. Although there are many "good" students, they have not been exposed to cutting-edge scholarship and diverse perspectives as a result. 

The full-time regular faculty are overly obsessed with distinguishing themselves from adjunct faculty. The full-time faculty often have opposed to including adjunct faculty in various research opportunities. Also, there have been unproductive competition and mutual exclusion among the academic disciplines, where collaboration and interdisciplinary research and teaching should take place. 

The university pays the same amount per course that I was paid 20 years ago when I started teaching at another private university, yet they think they are generous. The deans think that we are treated well because they pay above the "national average" for the adjunct faculty. If you are in this industry you would know that the national average does not measure up to a living wage.

job_title: Cook In Dining Hall in Saint Paul, MN
pros: It was very convenient given the fact that it was on campus, and flexible with scheduling. Getting a free meal per shift, and working with other students was enjoyable too.
cons: The pay, regardless of how hard you worked was kind of a joke, even for working in a kitchen. You had to put in time, rather than effort.

job_title: Research Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Flexible schedule, education and other benefits good (401k, tuition remission etc..)
cons: No internal advancement, organizational culture in silos, low collaboration.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Good people, lots of opportunities to learn and grow, stability, nice effort being made towards diversity and inclusion, renewed focus on developing a good culture with a sound value system
cons: Below average compensation, can be a little disorganized

job_title: Office Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Flexible work schedule, worked well since I was also a current student.  Ability to take on additional projects and additional responsibilities.
cons: Not really any cons.  The pay was reasonable due to the level of the position, but possibly not the highest student job that was available.

job_title: Admissions Specialist in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Great people
Positive work environment
Excellent benefits
Vibrant campus
Positive culture
cons:
Not much room for upward mobility - Too many people get a job and stay in that role for a long time (mostly because of the excellent benefits). This limits the opportunities for new employees to advance quickly. 
Lots of turnover in the last few years

review_title: I worked as a Statistics tutor for four years.

Can do homework during job

Help students
Easy to get subs

job_title: Instructor in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Class sizes are small, and so you can build relationships with students. 
Generous compensation. The management is interested in how employees are doing.
cons: Not much connection with co-workers. Need more projects where adjuncts and faculty work together (considering that adjuncts do a lot of the teaching work)

job_title: in Saint Paul, MN

review_title: Overall not bad, but could be better
job_title: Student Worker in Saint Paul, MN

cons: sometimes the managers are a bit weird though. strict policies regarding taking home food and texting. Not friendly to religion.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: It's a good community of people who genuinely enjoy working together. There are a lot of internal opportunities at this time as well.
cons: Undergoing a lot of change, which is hard. Also difficult to move from hourly to salaried staff.

job_title: Student Worker in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I worked at the OSF library. The manager is very laid back. This is great job to essentially sit and get paid for doing homework.
cons: The manager will probably forget who you are and not remember your name, even if you've been there for years.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Saint Paul, MN

cons: Some of the equipment is out of date, this depends on which professor you work for.

review_title: Good place to work - people care about one another

review_title: Only for the old and grey!
